column2: The saintly king Mitreyu was Divodāsa's son.

column1: ete vipañcitāḥ pakṣāḥ kṣatropetās tu bhārgavāḥ /

column2: Of them the youngest was Prishata who was Drupada's father.

column1: dhṛṣṭadyumnaḥ tudrupadād dhṛṣṭaketuś ca tatsutaḥ //
column2: Drupada's son was Dhaistadyumna whose son was Dhristaketu.

column2: These high-souled Somakās are known as Ajamidas.

column1: putrāṇām ajamīḍhasya somakatvaṃ mahātmanaḥ /
column2: And the sons of the high-souled Ajamida became known by the name of Somakas.

column2: king, the mother of your fore-fathers, Dhumini, desirous of having sons, was the third queen of Ajamida.

column1: sā tu putrārthinī devī vratacaryāsamāhitā / tapo varṣāśataṃ tepe strībhiḥ paramaduścaram //
column2: That lady, ever observant of vows, practised, for having a son, hard austerities which it is difficult for women to perform, extending over a million of years.

column1: hutvāgniṃ vidhivat sā tu pavitramitabhojanā / agnihotrakuśeṣv eva suṣvāpa janamejaya //
column2: Janamejaya, living on pure and restricted fare, offering duly oblation to fire she used to lie down on Kusa grass intended for fire-worship.

column1: ṛkṣaṃ sā janayām āsa dhūmavarṇaṃ sudarśanam //
column2: Ajamida knew the lady Dhumini and she gave birth to a smoky coloured beautiful son by name Riksha.

column1: yaḥ prayāgād apakramya kurukṣetraṃ cakāra ha //
column2: From him was born Samvarana who again begat Kuru, who passing by Prayaga, laid out the city of Kurukshetra –.

column1: tapyamāne tadā śakro yatrāsya varado babhau / puṇyaṃ ca ramaṇīyaṃ ca puṇyakṛdbhir niṣevitam /
column2: After that high-minded king had carried on penances for many thousand years and cultivated that holy and charming province resorted to by the pious, Sakra conferred on him a boon.

column1: tasyānvavāyaḥ sumahān yasya nāmnā stha kauravāḥ //
column2: His family was highly great from whom the Kouravas received their appellation –.

column1: kuroś ca putrāś catvāraḥ sudhanvā sudhanus tathā / parīkṣic ca mahābāhuḥ pravaraś cārimejayaḥ //
column2: Kuru had four sons, namely, Sudhanwa, Sudhana, the mighty armed Parikshit and Pravara at whose name the enemies used to tremble.

column1: sudhanvanas tu dāyādaḥ suhotro matimān smṛtaḥ / cyavanas tasya putras tu rājā dharmārthakovidaḥ //
column2: Sudhanwa's son was the intelligent Suhotra. His son was Chyavana who was well read in the Vedas and other scriptures. Chyavana's son was Krityajna.

column1: viśrutaṃ janayām āsa putram indrasakhaṃ nṛpaḥ //
column2: Celebrating many sacrifices that pious king begat a son equal to Indra in glory.

column1: caidyoparicaraṃ vīraṃ vasuṃ nāmāntarikṣagam /
column2: He was Vasu the king of Chedis who could range in the sky and move about in the air.

column1: caidyoparicarāj jajñe girikā sapta mānavān //
column2: He begat on Girika seven sons.

column1: pratyagrahaḥ kuśaś caiva yam āhur maṇivāhanam / mārutaś ca yaduś caiva matsyakālī ca sattamaḥ //
column2: They were the mighty car-warrior Vrihadratha the king of Magadha, Pratyagraha, Kusha, who passed by the name of Manivahana, Maruta, Yadu the fish Kāli and Sattama.

column1: bṛhadrathasya dāyādaḥ kuśāgro nāma viśrutaḥ / kuśāgrasyātmajo vidvān ṛṣabho nāma vīryavān //
column2: Vrihadratha's son was known by the name of Kushāgra –. His son was the learned and powerful Brishabha whose son was the pious Puspavāri.

column1: dāyādas tasya vikrānto rājā satyahitaḥ smṛtaḥ /
column2: His powerful son passed by the name of king Satyatulā -.

column1: ūrjasya saṃbhavaḥ putro yasya jajñe sa vīryavān //
column2: His son was the virtuous souled Urja whose son was Sambhava.

column1: śakale dve sa vai jāto jarayā saṃdhitaḥ sa tu /
column2: powerful son was born to Sambhava in two portions which were sewed up by Jarā.

column1: jarayā saṃdhito yasmāj jarāsaṃdhas tataḥ smṛtaḥ //
column2: And this son was accordingly named Jarāsandha -.

column1: sarvakṣatrasya jetāsau jarāsaṃdho mahābalaḥ /
column2: That highly powerful Jarāsandha defeated all the Kshatriyas.

column1: jarāsaṃdhasya putro vai sahadevaḥ pratāpavān //
column2: His son was the powerful Sahadeva.

column1: udāyir janayām āsa putraṃ paramadhārmikam /
column2: His son was the beautiful and highly illustrious Udayu who begat a highly pious son.

column1: śrutadharmeti nāmānaṃ magadhān yo 'vasad vibhuḥ /
column2: His name was Srutadharmā who lived in the country of Magadha.

column2: Parikshita's son was the pious Janamejaya. He had three sons who were all mighty car-warriors; they were Srutasena, Ugrasena and Bhimasena.

column1: ete sarve mahābhāgā vikrāntā balaśālinaḥ /
column2: They were all highly prosperous, powerful and brave.

column1: janamejayasya putrau tu suratho matimāṃs tathā /
column2: Besides these three sons Janamejaya begat on Manimati another two who were named Suratha and Matimān.

column1: surathasya tu vikrāntaḥ putro jajñe vidūrathaḥ //
column2: Suratha's son was the powerful Viduratha whose son was the mighty car-warrior Riksha.

column1: dvitīyaḥ sa babhau rājā nāmnā tenaiva saṃjñitaḥ //
column2: Though he was the second Riksha he was illustrious like the first.

column1: bhīmasenās trayo rājan dvāv eva janamejayau //
column2: king, in your family were born two Rikshas, two Parikshits, three Bhimasenas and two Janamejayas.

column1: ṛkṣasya tu dvitīyasya bhīmaseno 'bhavat sutaḥ /
column2: Riksha the second had a son by name Bhimasena whose son was Pratipa.

column1: devāpir bāhlikaś caiva traya eva mahārathāḥ //
column2: His sons were Shāntanu, Devapi and Vālhika who were all mighty car-warriors -.

column1: śāṃtanoḥ prasavas tv eṣa yatra jāto 'si pārthiva /
column2: king, the family, in which you have been born, is Shāntanu's family.

column1: bāhlikasya tu rājyaṃ vai saptabāhlyaṃ viśāṃ pate //
column2: king, Valhika had seven kingdoms.

column1: bāhlikasya sutaś caiva somadatto mahāyaśāḥ / jajñire somadattāt tu bhūrir bhūriśravāḥ śalaḥ //
column2: Valhika's son was the highly illustrious Somadatta whose sons were Bhuri, Bhurishrava and Shala.

column1: upādhyāyas tu devānāṃ devāpir abhavan muniḥ /
column2: The ascetic Devapi was the priest of the gods.

column1: cyavanasya putraḥ kṛtaka iṣṭaś cāsīn mahātmanaḥ // śāṃtanus tv abhavad rājā kauravāṇāṃ dhuraṃdharaḥ //
column2: He was the favourite son of the high-souled Chyavana. The king Shāntanu was the foremost of the Kuru kings. The family in which, great king, you have been born as Shāntanu's race.

column1: gāṅgaṃ devavrataṃ nāma putraṃ so 'janayat prabhuḥ /
column2: He begat on Gangā a son by name Devavrata.

column1: sa tu bhīṣma iti khyātaḥ pāṇḍavānāṃ pitāmahaḥ /
column2: He was celebrated by the name of Bhishma the grand-father of the Pāndavas.

column1: kālī vicitravīryaṃ tu janayām āsa bhārata / śāṃtanor dayitaṃ putraṃ dharmātmānam akalmaṣam //
column2: Kāli Satyavati gave birth to Vichitravirya who was the most favourite, virtuous-souled and sinless son of Shāntanu.

column1: kṛṣṇadvaipāyanac caiva kṣetre vaicitravīryake /
column2: Krishnadwaipāyana begat on Vichitravirya's wife Dhritarāstra, Pāndu and Vidura.

column1: dhṛtarāṣṭras tu gāndhāryāṃ putrānajanayac chatam /
column2: Dhritarastra begat on Gāndhāri a hundred sons, of whom Duryodhana was the eldest and became king -.

column1: pāṇḍor dhanaṃjayaḥ putraḥ saubhadras tasya cātmajaḥ /
column2: Pandu's son was Dhananjaya whose son was Abhimanyu who was given birth to by Subhadrā.

column1: abhimanyoḥ parīkṣit tu pitā tava janeśvara //
column2: king, your father Parikshit is Abhimanyu's son.

column1: eṣa te pauravo vaṃśo yatra jāto 'si pārthiva /
column2: king, such is the account of the Puru race in which you have been born.

column1: turvasos tu pravakṣyāmi druhyoś cānor yados tathā //
column2: shall presently describe the families of Turvasu, Drahyu, Puru and Yadu.

column1: turvasos tu suto vahnir vahner gobhānur ātmajaḥ / gobhānos tu suto rājā triśānur aparājitaḥ //
column2: Turvasu's son was Vanhi, whose son was Gobhānu, whose son was the irrepressible king Traisānu.

column1: karaṃdhamas tu triśānor maruttas tasya cātmajaḥ /
column2: His son was Karandhama whose son was Marutha.

column1: anyas tv āvikṣito rājā maruttaḥ kathitas tava //
column2: have mentioned before the name of another Marutta who was the son of Avikshit.

column1: anapatyo 'bhavad rājā yajvā vipuladakṣiṇaḥ /
column2: This king Marutta had no issue and accordingly he celebrated many Yajnas accompanied with profuse presents.

column1: duhitā saṃmatā nāma tasyāsīt pṛthivīpateḥ //
column2: king, he had a daughter by name Sarmatā.

column1: dakṣiṇārthaṃ hi sā dattā saṃvartāya mahātmane /
column2: He made a gift of her to the high-souled Samvarta.

column1: duḥṣantaṃ pauravaṃ cāpi lebhe putram akalmaṣam //
column2: Afterwards he obtained the sinless Puru king Dushmanta as his son -.

column1: evaṃ yayāteḥ śāpena jarāsaṃkramaṇe tadā / pauravaṃ turvasor vaṃśaḥ praviveśa nṛpottama //
column2: foremost of kings, thus on account of Yayāti's curse and of his transferring of his decrepitude Turvasu's line became identified with that of Kurus.

column1: duḥṣantasya tu dāyādaḥ śarutthāmaḥ prajeśvaraḥ /
column2: Dushmanta’s son was the king Karuthāma whose son was Akrida.

column1: pāṇḍyaś ca keralaś caiva kolaś colaś ca pārthivaḥ /
column2: He again had four sons whose names were Pāndya, Kerala, Kola and Chola.

column1: teṣāṃ janapadāḥ sphītāḥ pāṇḍyaś colaś ca keralāḥ //
column2: Their prosperous territories were respectively named Pāndya, Chola and Kerala.

column1: druhyos tu tanayo rājan babhrusenaś ca pārthivaḥ /
column2: king, Drahyu's sons were Babhru and Setu.

column1: aṅgārasetus tatputro marutāṃ patir ucyate //
column2: Setu's son was Angāra who was also known as lord of Maruts.

column1: yauvanāśvena samare kṛcchreṇa nihato balī /
column2: That powerful king was slain, with difficulty, by Youvānāshwa in battle.

column1: yuddhaṃ sumahad āsīd dhi māsān pari caturdaśa //
column2: He fought with him a dreadful combat for fourteen months -.

column1: aṅgārasya tu dāyādo gāndhāro nāma pārthivaḥ /
column2: The king Gāndhāra was Angāra's son, after whose name the celebrated Gāndhāra kingdom still passes.

column1: gāndhāradeśajāś caiva turagā vājināṃ varāḥ //
column2: The horses of that province are the best of their kind.

column1: anos tu putro dharmo 'bhūd dhṛtas tasyātmajo 'bhavat /
column2: Anu's son was Dharma whose son was Ghrita.

column1: dhṛtāt tu duduho jajñe pracetās tasya cātmajaḥ /
column2: Ghrita begat Duduha whose son was Prachetā.

column1: pracetasaḥ sucetās tu kīrtitā hy anavo mayā //
column2: Suchetā was Prachetā's son. have thus described the family of Anu.

column1: yador vaṃśaṃpravakṣyāmi jyeṣṭhasyottamatejasaḥ /
column2: Hear, shall now describe at length the most excellent and powerful family of the eldest Yadu -.

column1: babhūvus tu yadoḥ putrāḥ pañca devasutopamāḥ /

column1: sahasradaḥ payodaś ca kroṣṭā nīlo 'ñjikas tathā //
column2: They were Sahasrada, Payoda, Kroshta, Neela and Anjika.

column1: sahasradasya dāyādās trayaḥ paramadhārmikāḥ /
column2: king, Sahasrada had three highly pious sons–Haihaya, Haya and Venuhaya.

column1: hehayasyābhavat putro dharmanetra iti śrutaḥ / dharmanetrasya kāntas tu kāntaputrās tato 'bhavan //
column2: Haihaya's son was celebrated by the name of Dharmanetra. His son was Kārta whose son was Sāhanja –.

column1: sāhañjanī nāmapurī tena rājñā niveśitā //
column2: That king founded a city named Sāhanjani.

column1: māhiṣmatī nāma purī yena rājñā niveśitā //
column2: The king Mahishmān was his son. By him the city of Mahishmati was founded.

column1: āsīn mahiṣmataḥ putro bhadraśreṇyaḥ pratāpavān /
column2: The powerful Bhadrasenya was Mahishmān's son.

column1: vārāṇasyadhipo rājā kathitaḥ pūrvam eva tu /
column2: As recount ed by me before he was the ruler of Bārānashi.

column1: bhadraśreṇyasya dāyādo durdamo nāma viśrutaḥ //
column2: Bhadrasenya's son was Durdama –. Durdama’s son was Kanka who was very intelligent.

column1: kanakasya tu dāyādāś catvāro lokaviśrutāḥ / kṛtavīryaḥ kṛtaujāś ca kṛtadhanvā tathaiva ca /
column2: Kanka had four sons well-known in the world, namely Kritavirya, Kritoujā, Kritavarmā and Kritāgni.

column1: yaḥ sa bāhusahasreṇa saptadvīpeśvaro 'bhavat /
column2: From Kritavirya, Arjuna was born who had a thousand arms and became the emperor of the seven insular continents.

column1: jigāya pṛthivīm eko rathenādityavarcasā //
column2: He alone, in his car effulgent like the sun, conquered the world –.

column1: dattam ārādhayām āsa kārtavīryo 'trisaṃbhavam // tasmai datto varān prādāc caturo bhūritejasaḥ /
column2: Having carried on hard austerities for a million of years that royal son of Kritavirya succeeded in pleasing Atri's son Datta who conferred on him four very powerful boons.

column1: pūrvaṃ bāhusahasraṃ tu prārthitaṃ paramaṃ varam //
column2: The first of these, was that he would get one thousand arms –.

column1: adharme dhīyamānasya sadbhiḥ syān me nibarhaṇam / ugreṇa pṛthivīṃ jitvā dharmeṇaivānurañjanam //
column2: The second was that the sages would prevent him from imbibing irreligious thoughts. The third was that having conquered the world with fierce Kshatriya energies he would please his subjects duly.

column1: saṃgrāmān subahūñ jitvā hatvā cārīn sahasraśaḥ / saṃgrāme vartamānasya vadhaṃ cābhyadhikād raṇe // tasya bāhusahasraṃ tu yudhyataḥ kila bhārata / yogād yogeśvarasyāgre prādurbhavati māyayā //
column2: The fourth was that when he would gain many battles and destroy thousands of enemies he would be killed in battle by a highly powerful man –. king, when that ascetic king engaged in a battle, he, by virtue of asceticism and illusory energy, acquired thousand arms.

column1: teneyaṃ pṛthivī kṛtsnā saptadvīpā sapattanā / sasamudrā sanagarā ugreṇa vidhinā jitā //
column2: By his dreadful prowess he conquered the earth consisting of seven insular continents, many mountains and oceans.

column1: tena saptasu dvīpeṣu sapta yajñaśatāni vai / prāptāni vidhinā rājñā śrūyante janamejaya //
column2: Janamejaya, we have heard that king duly celebrated seven hundred Yajnas in the seven insular continents –.

column1: sarve yajñā mahābāho tasyāsan bhūridakṣiṇāḥ / sarve kāñcanayūpāś ca sarve kāñcanavedayaḥ //
column2: large-armed one, in those Yajnas thousands of presents were given away. In those Yajnas golden sacrificial posts and altars were set up.

column1: sarve devair mahārāja vimānasthair alaṃkṛtāḥ / gandharvair apsarobhiś ca nityam evopaśobhitāḥ //
column2: They were all adorned with gods in celestial cars, with Gandharvas and Apsarās.

column1: yasya yajñe jagau gāthāṃ gandharvo nāradas tathā /
column2: In his Yajnas, the Gandharvas and Nārada sang hymns.

column1: varīdāsātmajo vidvān mahimnā tasya vismitaḥ //
column2: Seeing his glory Baridasa was struck with wonder -.

column1: na nūnaṃ kārtavīryasya gatiṃ yāsyanti pārthivāḥ / yajñair dānais tapobhir vā vikrameṇa śrutena vā //
column2: Narada said:—None, among the kings, will attain to the dignity of Kārtavirya by celebrating Yajnas, making presents, by his prowess and knowledge of scriptures.

column1: sa hi saptasu dvīpeṣu khaḍgī carmī śarāsanī / rathī dvīpān anucaran yogī saṃdṛśyate nṛbhiḥ //
column2: People saw him ranging in his car simultaneously, by virtue of his Yoga power, over the seven insular continents with his armour, sword and bow.

column1: anaṣṭadravyatā caiva na śoko na ca vibhramaḥ / prabhāveṇa mahārājñaḥ prajā dharmeṇa rakṣataḥ //
column2: On account of his righteously protecting his subjects that great king lost nothing, never felt any grief nor made a mistake. He was the owner of all sorts of jewels and Lord Paramount.

column1: sa eva paśupālo 'bhūt kṣetrapālaḥ sa eva ca / sa eva vṛṣṭyā parjanyo yogitvād arjuno 'bhavat //
column2: He performed many Yajnas and owned extensive lands. He was like Indra on account of profuse showers and like Arjuna for his ascetic powers.

column1: sa vai bāhusahasreṇa jyāghātakaṭhinatvacā / bhāti raśmisahasreṇa śaradīva ca bhāskaraḥ //
column2: Like the sun shining with all its thousand rays during the autumn he shone with his thousand arms with armours on and hardened by the strokes of his bow-string.

column1: sa hi nāgān manuṣyeṣu māhiṣmatyāṃ mahādyutiḥ / karkoṭakasutāñ jitvā puryāṃ tasyāṃ nyaveśayat //
column2: Having defeated the sons of the Nāga Karkotaka that highly effulgent king occupied his city, by name Mahishmati, for the habitation of mankind.

column1: sa vai vegaṃ samudrasya prāvṛṭkāle 'mbujekṣaṇaḥ / krīḍann iva bhujodbhinnaṃ pratisrotaś cakāra ha //
column2: While sporting in the water during the rains that lotus-eyed king changed the current of the ocean with his thousand arms.

column1: luṇṭhitā krīḍatā tena phenasragdāmamālinī / caladūrmisahasreṇa śaṅkitābhyeti narmadā //
column2: While he sported and bathed in the water of the river Narmadā engarlanded with her foam she used to approach him in fear with her thousand waves.

column1: tasya bāhusahasreṇa kṣubhyamāṇe mahodadhau / bhayān nilīnā niśceṣṭāḥ pātālasthā mahāsurāḥ //
column2: When he used to agitate the mighty deep with his thousand arms the great Asuras, living in the nether region, became inert and silent.

column1: cūrṇīkṛtamahāvīciṃ calanmīnamahātimim / mārutāviddhaphenaugham āvartakṣobhaduḥsaham // prāvartayat tadā rājā sahasreṇa ca bāhunā / devāsurasamākṣiptaḥ kṣīrodam iva mandaraḥ //
column2: As the mount Mandāra, when thrown off by the gods and demons, agitated the ocean of milk so did the king Arjuna, the son of Kritavirya, crush down the waves of the ocean, shake the fish and other huge acquatic animals, whirl the foam with air and create whirlpools of water.

column1: mandarakṣobhacakitā amṛtotpādaśaṅkitāḥ / sahasotpatitā bhītā bhīmaṃ dṛṣṭvā nṛpottamam // natā niścalamūrdhāno babhūvus te mahoragāḥ /
column2: Awakened by the motion of the mount Mandāra, terrified by the production of ambrosia and troubled all on a sudden, the huge Uragas became motionless and humble at the sight of that terrible man.

column1: sāyāhne kadalīkhaṇḍaiḥ kampitās tasya vāyunā //
column2: They trembled before him like plantain leaves shaken by the evening breeze –.

column1: sa vai baddhvā dhanur jyābhir utsiktaṃ pañcabhiḥ śaraiḥ / laṅkeśaṃ mohayitvā tu sabalaṃ rāvaṇaṃ balāt / nirjityaiva samānīya māhiṣmatyāṃ babandha tam //
column2: Having vanquished, with his might, the haughty king of Lanka, Rāvana with his army and made him senseless with five arrows he bound him with his bow-string, brought him to the city of Mahishmati and kept him in chains there.

column1: abhiṣekārdrakeśena rājñā rañjanakāmyayā / jetavyānīndriyāṇy ādau taj jaye hi dhruvo jayaḥ // samyagvartitukāmasya viśeṣeṇa mahīpateḥ / nayānām upadeśena nāsti lokasamo guruḥ //
column2: That king, desirous of pleasing his subjects, who has his hairs wet with the water of installation, should first of all conquer his senses, for mastery over senses is the sure victory, The king, who wishes to keep his position always intact and strong, should instruct his men in moral laws for there is no other preceptor like him to the people.

column1: vyasaneṣu jaghanyasya dharmamadhyasya dhīmataḥ / balajyeṣṭhasya nṛpater nāsti sāmantajaṃ bhayam //
column2: If when placed in the midst of dangers and vices, an intelligent king strengthens himself by his army he is not to entertain any fear of his enemies.

column1: sahajair badhyate sarvaḥ pravṛddhair indriyāribhiḥ /
column2: All men are killed by their senses, the powerful enemies born with them.

column1: amitrāṇāṃ priyakarair mohair adhṛtir īśvaraḥ //
column2: An impatient king is slain by the false notion of good done to them by their enemies.

column1: yat tvayā strīkṛte mohāt sabalo rāvaṇo hataḥ /
column2: On account of your wife, you have, out of foolish attachment, killed Rāvana with his army.

column1: naitad aupayikaṃ manye mahat te karma kutsitam //
column2: do not consider that sinful action of yours as great and becoming.

column1: prahṛtaṃ rākṣase nīce naiṣa dṛṣṭaḥ satāṃ vidhiḥ //
column2: Living in a forest and observing a vow you have killed a mean Rakshasa. Such a conduct is not seen in the pious.

column1: satām akrodhajo dharmaḥ śubhāṃ nayati sadgatim /
column2: Virtue, begotten of forbearance, takes the pious to an auspicious and righteous station.

column1: yat tvayā nihato mohād dūṣitāś ca vanaukasaḥ //
column2: Out of ignorance you have killed Rāvana and honoured the forest ranging Vanaras.

column1: sa eva rāvaṇo dhanyo yas tvayā vratacāriṇā / strīnimittaṃ hato yuddhe grāmyān dharmān avekṣatā //
column2: Indeed Rāvana is blessed, since you, while observing a vow, killed him in battle for your wife, in pursance of the conduct of ordinary men.

column1: yadi te sa hataḥ saṃkhye durbuddhir ajitendriyaḥ /
column2: That wicked-minded Rāvana, who has not controlled his senses, has been killed by you in battle.

column1: yudhyasvādya mayā sārdhaṃ mṛdhe yady asi vīryavān //
column2: You are therefore capable of fighting. Come and fight with me to-day.

column1: tasya dūtasya tac chrutvā bhāṣitaṃ tattvavādinaḥ / dhairyād asaṃbhrāntavapuḥ sasmitaṃ rāghavo 'bravīt // asad etat tvayā dūta kathitaṃ tasya gauravāt /
column2: Hearing those words of that harsh-speeched emissary, Rāma, out of forbearance, smilingly said to him:— Emissary, what you have said, out of honor to that night-ranger, is unfair, since you have been blaming me and considering yourself at ease –.

column1: yady ahaṃ satpathe mūḍho yadi vā rāvaṇo hataḥ / yadi vā me hṛtā bhāryā tasya kā paridevanā // na vāṅmātreṇa duṣyanti sādhavaḥ satpathe sthitāḥ /
column2: What is there to blame, if, wending the ways of righteousness, have been stupified, if Rāvana has been slain and my wife has been carried away, The virtuous, always following the ways of morality, do not blame others even with their words.

column1: jāgarti ca yathā daivaṃ sadā satsv itareṣu ca // kṛtaṃ dūtena yat kāryaṃ gaccha tvaṃ dūta māciram /
column2: As the God is always awake for the pious, He is equally so for the wicked, You have done what is the duty of a messenger. Go now and make no delay.

column1: nātmaślāghiṣu nīceṣu praharantīha madvidhāḥ //
column2: Persons like me do not hurt the mean: who are fond of making too much of themselves.

column1: ayaṃ mamānujo bhrātā śatrughnaḥ śatrutāpanaḥ /
column2: Here is my younger brother Satrughna, the repressor of enemies in battle.

column1: tasya daityasya durbuddhe mṛdhe pratikariṣyati //
column2: He will wait for that wicked-minded demon.

column1: evam uktaḥ sa dūtas tu yayau saumitriṇā saha / anujñāto narendreṇa rāghaveṇa mahātmanā //
column2: Thus addressed by Rāma and commanded by that king that messenger set out with Satrughna.

column1: sa śīghrayānaḥ saṃprāptas tad dānavavanaṃ mahat / cakre niveśaṃ saumitrir vanānte yuddhalālasaḥ //
column2: Ascending upon a quick-coursing car, Sumitra's son Satrughna repaired to the huge forest of Madhu and desirous of entering into a battle pitched a tent there –.

column1: tato dūtasya vacanāt sa daityaḥ krodhamūrcchitaḥ /
column2: Thereupon hearing the words of that messenger the demon Lavana was beside himself with anger.

column1: jaghane tad vanaṃ kṛtvā yuddhāyābhimukhaḥ sthitaḥ //
column2: Leaving behind the Madhu forest he started for battle.

column1: ubhayor eva dhṛtayoḥ śūrayo raṇamūrdhani // tau śaraiḥ sādhuniśitair anyonyam abhijaghnatuḥ /
column2: Then there took place a terrible encounter between Satrughna and Lavana. They were both heroic and mighty bowmen. Both of them struck each other with sharpened arrows.

column1: na ca tau yuddhavaimukhyaṃ śramaṃ vāpy upajagmatuḥ //
column2: None of them fled back from the battle-field and none of them felt himself tired -.

column1: atha saumitriṇā bāṇaiḥ pīḍito dānavo yudhi / tataḥ sa śūlarahitaḥ paryahīyata dānavaḥ //
column2: Thereupon greatly assailed in battle by Satrughna's shafts the Dānava Lavana met with discomfiture for he had not his mace with him.

column1: sa gṛhītvāṅkuśaṃ caiva devair dattavaraṃ raṇe / karṣaṇaṃ sarvabhūtānāṃ lavaṇo virarāsa ha //
column2: Afterwards taking up a celestial Sankhusha, that was given to him as a boon and was capable of grinding all creatures, Lavana began to shout in the battle.

column1: praveśayitum ārabdho lavaṇo rāghavānujam / sa rukmatsarum udyamya śatrughnaḥ śatrutāpanaḥ / śiraś ciccheda khaḍgena lavaṇasya mahāmṛdhe //
column2: He caught of hold Satrughna's turban with it and began to draw in Rāghava's younger brother. Thereat taking up a most excellent dagger having a golden handle Satrughna cut off with it Lavana's head in that great battle.

column1: sa hatvā dānavaṃ saṃkhye saumitrir mitranandanaḥ / tad vanaṃ tasya daityasya cicchedāstreṇa buddhimān //
column2: Having slain that demon Lavana in battle, that heroic son of Sumitra, who gives delight to his friends, cleared off his forest with his weapons.

column1: chittvā vanaṃ sa saumitrir niveśam abhirocayat / bhavāya tasya deśasya purīṃ paramadharmavit //
column2: Having cleared that forest that pious son of Sumitrā, Satrughna, built a city there for the well-being of that province and desired to live there.

column1: tasmin madhuvanasthāne mathurā nāma sā purī / śatrughnena purā sṛṣṭā hatvā taṃ dānavaṃ raṇe //
column2: Having killed, in the days of yore, the demon Lavana in Mudhu forest Setrughna built a city there by name Mathurā –.

column1: sā purī paramodārā sāṭṭaprākāratoraṇā / sphītā rāṣṭrasamākīrṇā samṛddhabhavanākulā //
column2: That great city was adorned with walls, gate ways and doors. It contained many villages, high buildings and gardens.

column1: udyānavanasaṃpannā susīmā supratiṣṭhitā /
column2: Its boundaries were well laid and it was beautifully built.

column1: cayāṭṭālakakeyūrā prāsādavarakuṇḍalā / susaṃvṛtadvāramukhī catvarodgārahāsinī //
column2: The ditches were like the ornament that a woman uses round her waist. The buildings, made of stone and bricks, were like Keyuras. Beautiful palaces were like the ear-rings.

column1: arogavīrapuruṣā hastyaśvarathasaṃkulā /
column2: It contained many healthy heroes, elephants, horses and cars.

column1: ardhacandrapratīkāśā yamunātīraśobhitā // puṇyāpaṇavatī durgā ratnasaṃcayagarvitā /
column2: It resembled a crescent and was situate on the bank of Yamuna. It contained beautiful markets and was proud of her collection of jems. The fields there were full of corns.

column1: kṣetrāṇi rasavanty asyāḥ kāle devaś ca varṣati //
column2: The king of gods Indra used to pour showers in proper season. Men and women there were always delightful.

column1: tasyāṃ puryāṃ mahāvīryo rājā bhojakulodvahaḥ /
column2: The highly powerful king Surasena, born in the race of Bhojas, reigned there.

column1: ugrasena iti khyāto mahāsenaparākramaḥ //
column2: He was powerful like Mahāsena and was celebrated by the name of Ugrasena –.

column1: tasya putratvam āpanno yo 'sauviṣṇo tvayā hataḥ /
column2: He whom thou hast killed, Vishnu, is his son.

column1: kālanemir mahādaityaḥ saṃgrāme tārakāmaye // kaṃso nāma viśālākṣo bhojavaṃśavivardhanaḥ /
column2: The Daitya, by name Kālanemi, whom thou didst slay in the battle of which Tāraka was the root, is born as Kansa, and is the scion of the Bhoja race.

column1: rājā pṛthivyāṃ vikhyātaḥ siṃhavispaṣṭavikramaḥ //
column2: That king, who treads like a lion, is celebrated in the world –.

column1: bhayadaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ satpathād bāhyatāṃ gataḥ //
column2: He is a terror to all the kings of the world and a dread to all creatures. He is always beyond the path of righteousness.

column1: dāruṇābhiniveśena dāruṇenāntarātmanā / yuktas tenaiva darpeṇa prajānāṃ lomaharṣaṇaḥ //
column2: He is highly persevering and ruthless. He is so very haughty to his subjects that seeing him their hairs stand erect.

column1: na rājadharmābhirato nātmapakṣasukhāvahaḥ / nātmarājyapriyakaraś caṇḍaḥ kararuciḥ sadā //
column2: He never observes his royal duties and is never a source of pleasure to his own men. He never does any good to his kingdom and behaves always like a tyrant.

column1: sa kaṃsas tatra saṃbhūtas tvayā yuddhe parājitaḥ /
column2: He, who was vanquished by thee in Tāraka battle, is now born as Kansa in the Bhoja race.

column1: kravyādo bādhate lokān āsureṇāntarātmanā //
column2: That one, living on meat, is oppressing all the worlds, with his demonaic heart.

column1: keśī nāma hayo jātaḥ sa tasyaiva jaghanyajaḥ //
column2: He, who was like a horse and known by the name, Hayagriva, is born as Keshi the youngest brother of Kansa.

column1: sa duṣṭo heṣitapaṭuḥ kesarī niravagrahaḥ / vṛndāvane vasaty eko nṛṇāṃ māṃsāni bhakṣayan //
column2: That wicked bodiless demon with manes, neighing like a horse, is now living alone in Vrindāvana. He lives on human flesh.

column1: ariṣṭo baliputras tu kakudmī vṛṣarūpadhṛk / gavām aritvam āpannaḥ kāmarūpī mahāsuraḥ //
column2: Bali's son Aristha is born as the great Asura Kakudmi, capable of assuming forms of his own accord. Adopting the form of a bull he has become an enemy of the kine.

column1: riṣṭo nāma diteḥ putro variṣṭho dānaveṣu yaḥ / sa kuñjaratvam āpanno daityaḥ kaṃsasya vāhanaḥ //
column2: Diti's son Ristha, the foremost of Danavas, is born as Kansa's elephant.

column1: lambo nāmeti vikhyāto yo 'saudaityeṣu darpitaḥ /
column2: That dreadful demon Lamva is born as Pralamva.

column1: śikharo nāma balavān ya āsīd dānavarṣabhaḥ / khara ity ucyate daityo dhenukaḥ so 'surottamaḥ /
column2: He is living under a fig-tree by name Bhandara. That demon, who was known by the name of Khara, is born as the dreadful Asura Dhanuka.

column1: ghoraṃ tālavanaṃ daityaś caraty utsārayan prajāḥ //
column2: Living in the forest of palm-trees he is making a havoc of creatures.

column1: varāhaś ca kiśoraś ca tāv ubhau dānavottamau / mallau raṅgagatau tau tu jātau cāṇūramuṣṭikau //
column2: Those two foremost of Danavas, by name Varaha and Kishora, have been born as wrestlers Chanuka and Musthika who are always at the arena.

column1: yau tau mayaś ca tāraś ca dānavau dānavāntaka / prāgjyotiṣe tau bhaumasya narakasya pure ratau //
column2: Those two Danavas Maya and Tara, who were like death even to the demons, are now living in the city of Bhumi's son Naraka, by name Prāgyotish.

column1: ete daityā vinihatās tvayā viṣṇo nirākṛtāḥ /
column2: Nārāyana, thou didst slay all these Danavas and divest them of their forms.

column1: mānuṣaṃ vapur āsthāya bādhante bhuvi mānavān //
column2: Assuming human bodies they are now oppressing the people of the world.

column1: tvatkathādveṣiṇaḥ sarve tvanmayān ghnanti mānavān /
column2: They oppose the chanting of thy name and destroy thy votaries.

column1: tava prasādāt teṣāṃ vai dānavānāṃ kṣayo bhavet //
column2: By thy favour only they will meet with destruction.

column1: tava te divi bibhyanti tvatto bibhyanti sāgare /
column2: In heaven they are afraid of thee, in ocean they are afraid of thee and even on earth they afraid of thee.

column1: pṛthivyāṃ bibhyati tvatto nānyasya tu kathaṃcana //
column2: There is no other source of fear to them.

column1: durvṛttasya hatasyāpi tvayā nānyena śrīdhara /
column2: Sridhar, thou dost slay the wicked Dānavas; none else can accomplish their destruction.

column1: divaś cyutasya daityasya gatir bhavati medinī //
column2: The Daityas, who are sent away from heaven, find refuge on earth.

column1: vyutthitasya tu medinyāṃ hatasya nṛśarīriṇaḥ / durlabhaṃ svargagamanaṃ tvayi jāgrati keśava //
column2: Keshava, thou being awake, it is difficult for that demon to go again to heaven, who, on his being slain in the celestial region, again rises up assuming a human body.

column1: tad āgaccha svayaṃ viṣṇo gacchāva pṛthivītalam /
column2: Therefore, Nārāyana, do thou come to the world. We are also descending on earth.

column1: dānavānāṃ vināśāya visṛjātmānam ātmanā //
column2: Do thou create your own self for the destruction of Dānavas.

column1: mūrtayo hi tavāvyaktā dṛśyādṛśyāḥ surottamaiḥ /
column2: The forms of thine, which are not manifest, are both visible and invisible to the celestials.

column1: tāsu sṛṣṭās tvayā devāḥ saṃbhaviṣyanti bhūtale //
column2: In those forms, the gods, created by thee, shall descend on earth.

column1: tavāvataraṇe viṣṇo kaṃsaḥ sa vinaśiṣyati / setsyate ca sa kāryārtho yasyārthe bhūmir āgatā //
column2: Vishnu, when thou shalt come down on earth, Kansa will not be able to reign and the object, for which the earth has come, will also be accomplished.

column1: tvaṃ bhārate kāryagurus tvaṃ cakṣus tvaṃ parāyaṇaḥ /
column2: Thou art the preceptor of all works in the land of Bharata, thou art the eye of all and the supreme refuge.

column1: tad āgaccha hṛṣīkeśa kṣitau tāñ jahi dānavān //
column2: Therefore, Hrishikesha do thou come on earth and slay those wicked Dānavas .

column1: vaiśaṃpāyana uvāca nāradasya vacaḥ śrutvā sasmitaṃ madhusūdanaḥ / pratyuvāca śubhaṃ vākyaṃ vareṇyaḥ prabhur īśvaraḥ //
column2: Vaishampayana said:—Hearing the words of Nārada the Lord Madhusudana, the master of gods, smilingly said in auspicious words :— Nārada, listen to a proper reply to all these words which you have addressed to me for the well-being of the three worlds.

column1: viditā dehino jātā mayaite bhuvi dānavāḥ /
column2: It is known to me that all these Dānavas, assuming human forms, have been born on earth.

column1: jānāmi kaṃsaṃ saṃbhūtam ugrasenasutaṃ bhuvi / keśinaṃ cāpi jānāmi daityaṃ turagavigraham // hastinaṃ cotpalāpīḍaṃ mallau cāṇūramuṣṭikau /
column2: know too that Kansa is born as the son of Ugrasena on earth. know also that Keshi is born as a horse. know also the elephant Kuvalayapida, the wrestlers Chānura and Mushthika and the demon Arishtha in the shape of a bull.

column1: vidito me kharaś caiva pralambaś ca mahāsuraḥ /
column2: Khara and the great Asura Pralamva are also known to me.

column1: sā ca me viditā vipra pūtanā duhitā baleḥ //
column2: Bali's daughter Putanā is also well known to me.

column1: kāliyaṃ cāpi jānāmi yamunāhradagocaram /
column2: know also Kāliya who is living in the lake of Yamunā and who has entered there in fear of Vinatā's son.

column1: vidito me jarāsaṃdhaḥ sthito mūrdhni mahīkṣitām / prāgjyotiṣapure cāpi narakaṃ sādhu tarkaye //
column2: know also Jarāsandha who is the head of all kings; and the demon Naraka, who is living in the city of Prāgyotish, is also very well-known to me.

column1: mānuṣe pārthive loke mānuṣatvam upāgatam /
column2: In the city of Shonitpura on earth Bāna is born as a man.

column1: dṛptaṃ bāhusahasreṇa devair api sudurjayam /
column2: That energetic and haughty demon, of thousand arms, is invincible even unto the gods.

column1: mayy āsaktāṃ ca jānāmi bhāratīṃ mahatīṃ dhuram /
column2: know also that the great charge of Bhāratvarsa lies with me -.

column1: tac ca sarvaṃ vijānāmi yathā sthāsyanti te nṛpāḥ //
column2: know also how all these kings will disappear.

column1: kṣayo bhuvi mayā dṛṣṭaḥ śakraloke ca satkriyā / teṣāṃ puruṣadehānām aparāvṛttivartinām //
column2: The destruction of those danavas, in human forms, who never come back from battle-field and the rejoicing of the region of Sakra has also been seen by me.

column1: saṃpravekṣyāmy ahaṃ yogam ātmanaś ca parasya ca /
column2: For myself and for others shall enter into Yoga.

column1: saṃprāpya pārthivaṃ lokaṃ mānuṣatvam upāgataḥ // kaṃsādīṃś cāpi tān sarvān vadhiṣyāmi mahāsurān /
column2: Going to the region of men and assuming a human form shall bring about the destruction of all those mighty demons headed by Kansa.

column1: tena tena vidhānena yena yaḥ śāntim eṣyati //
column2: shall slay him by that means by which he will enjoy peace –.

column1: anupraviśya yogena tās tā hi gatayo mama /
column2: By my Yoga shall resort to all these means.

column1: amīṣām amarendrāṇāṃ hantavyā ripavo yudhi //
column2: It is my incumbent duty to destroy all those enemies of the gods in battle.

column1: jagatyarthe kṛto yo 'yam aṃśotsargo mahātmabhiḥ / suradevarṣigandharvair etac cānumataṃ mama //
column2: shall kill the foes of all those great ones who have sacrificed themselves on behalf of the earth, of all those gods, Rishis and Gandharvas who have come down on earth at my behest.

column1: viniścayo hi prāg eva nāradāyaṃ kṛto mayā /
column2: Nārada, have already formed this resolution.

column1: nivāsaṃ tu na me brahmā vidadhāti pitāmahaḥ //
column2: Let the grand-father Brahmā make a house there for me.

column1: yatra deśe yathā jāto yena veṣeṇa vā vasan / tān ahaṃ samare hanyāṃ tan me brūhi pitāmaha //
column2: grand-father, do thou relate to me, how, born in what country and living in what house shall kill them .

column1: brahmovāca nārāyaṇemaṃ siddhārtham upāyaṃ śṛṇu me vibho /
column2: Brahma said:— lord, Nārāyana, hear from me of that key to success and who your parents will be on earth.

column1: bhuvi yas te janayitā jananī ca bhaviṣyati //
column2: In order to glorify their family you will be born in the race of Yādavas.

column1: tāṃś cāsurān samutsādya vaṃśaṃ kṛtvātmano mahat / sthāpayiṣyasi maryādāṃ nṛṇāṃ tan me niśāmaya //
column2: Eradicating these Asuras for good and multiplying your great family you will establish the orders of mankind. Hear from me about this.

column1: purā hi kaśyapo viṣṇo varuṇasya mahātmanaḥ / jahāra yajñiyā gāvaḥ payodāś ca mahāmakhe //
column2: Nārāyana, in the days of yore, in the great sacrifice of the high-souled Varuna, Kashyapa stole away all the cows giving milk for the sacrifice.

column1: aditiḥ surabhiś cobhe dve bhārye kaśyapasya tu /
column2: Kashyapa had two wives, Aditi and Surabhi who did not wish to accept the kine from Varuna.

column1: tato māṃ varuṇo 'bhyetya praṇamya śirasānataḥ / uvāca bhagavan gāvo guruṇā me hṛtā iti //
column2: Thereupon coming to me and bowing with his head down Varuna said revered one, the preceptor has stolen away all my kine.

column1: kṛtakāryo hi gās tās tu nānujānāti me guruḥ /
column2: Having accomplished his object, even, father, he has not ordered the return of those kine.

column1: anvavartata bhārye dve aditiṃ surabhiṃ tathā //
column2: He is under the control of his two wives Aditi and Surabhi.

column1: mama tā hy akṣayā gāvo divyāḥ kāmadughā vibho / caranti sagārān sarvān rakṣitāḥ svena tejasā //
column2: lord, all those my kine give heavenly and eternal milk whenever wished. Protected by their own power they range in the seas. They perpetually yeild milk like unto the ambrosia of gods.

column1: kas tā dharṣayituṃ śakto mama gāḥ kaśyapād ṛte /
column2: Save Kashyapa there is none else who can charm them.

column1: prabhur vā vyutthito brahman gurur vā yadi vetaraḥ /
column2: Brahmā, a master, a preceptor or whoever he may be if one goes astray thou dost control him.

column1: tvayā niyamyāḥ sarve vai tvaṃ hi naḥ paramā gatiḥ //
column2: Thou art our supreme refuge.

column1: yadi prabhavatāṃ daṇḍo loke kāryam ajānatām / na vidyate lokaguro na syur vai lokasetavaḥ //
column2: preceptor of the world, if punishment is not meted out to powerful persons who do not know their own work, then the order of the world will not exist.

column1: yathā vāstu tathā vāstu kartavye bhagavān prabhuḥ /
column2: Thou art omnipotent and lord of all.

column1: nandagopas tu tac chrutvā vajrapātopamaṃ vacaḥ / ārtaḥ skhalitavikrāntas taṃ jagāma hradottamam //
column2: Hearing those words like unto the fall of a thunderbolt the milk-man Nanda was greatly distressed with sorrow and speedily went to that most excellent lake.

column1: sabālayuvatīvṛddhaḥ sa ca saṃkarṣaṇo yuvā /
column2: All the inhabitants of Vraja, accompanied by the youthful Sangkarshana, boys, old men and young ladies, arrived at the watery abode of that king of serpents.

column1: ākrīḍaṃ pannagendrasya janas taṃ samupāgamat // nandagopamukhā gopās te sarve sāśrulocanāḥ /
column2: Having reached the the bank of that lake all the milkmen, headed by Nanda, stricken with shame, surprise and sorrow, began to bewail with their eyes full of tears.

column1: kecit tu kṛṣṇa hā heti hā dhig ity apare punaḥ /
column2: Some cried, exclaiming Oh, son! while others said Alas! woe to us! –.

column2: Whereas others, assailed greatly by fear, cried Alas! We are all slain! The women, crying aloud, said to Yashodā Alas! We are all killed.

column1: yā paśyasi priyaṃ putraṃ sarparājavaśaṃgataṃ /
column2: Behold your son brought under the control of the king of serpents.

column1: saṃditaṃ sarpabhogena kṛṣyamāṇaṃ yathā mṛgam //
column2: He is trembling there as if churned, like ambrosia, by the hood of the serpent –.

column1: aśmasāramayaṃ nūnaṃ hṛdayaṃ te 'bhilakṣyate / putraṃ katham imaṃ dṛṣṭvā yaśode nāvadīryate //
column2: Forsooth, your heart is made of stone, since it is not breaking assunder even beholding your son in this plight.

column2: See, the milkman Nanda, filled with grief, is standing on the bank of the lake like one unconscious, fixing his look on the face of his son.

column1: yaśodām anugacchantyaḥ sarpāvāsam imaṃ hradam /
column2: Following Yashodā we shall rather enter into this lake, the abode of the serpents.

column1: praviśāmo na yāsyāmaḥ sarvā dāmodaraṃ vinā //
column2: And still we will not return to Vraja without Dāmodara.

column1: divasaḥ ko vinā sūryaṃ vinā candreṇa kā niśā / vinā vṛṣeṇa kā gāvo vinā kṛṣṇena ko vrajaḥ /

column1: vinā kṛṣṇaṃ na yāsyāmo vivatsā iva dhenavaḥ //
column2: Separated from Krishna we shall not go there like a cow without her calf.

column1: vilāpaṃ nandagopasya yaśodāṃ rudatīṃ tathā / ekabhāvaśarīrajña ekadeho dvidhākṛtaḥ / saṃkarṣaṇas tu saṃkruddho babhāṣe kṛṣṇam avyayam // kṛṣṇa kṛṣṇa mahābāho gopānāṃ nandivardhana /
column2: Hearing the lamentations of the male and female inhabitants of Vraja, and of Nanda and the cries of Yashodā, Sangkarshana, who though of one mind, one body and one intelligence, was still a separate person, said in anger to Krishna –:— Krishna, thou of large-arms, thou who dost enhance the delight of the milkmen, do thou soon destroy this venomous serpent-king.

column1: ime no bāndhavās tāta tvāṃ matvā mānuṣaṃ prabho / paridevanti karuṇam sarve mānuṣabuddhayaḥ //
column2: my brother, my lord, all these our relations have human understandings and so they are bewailing for thee considering thee a human being.

column1: tac chrutvā rauhiṇeyasya vākyaṃ saṃjñāsamīritam / vikrīḍyāsphoṭayad bāhū tad bhittvā bhogabandhanam //
column2: Hearing those wise words of Rohini's son, Krishna sportively raised up his arms and rose up snapping the fetters of the serpents.

column1: tasya padbhyāṃ athākramya bhogarāśiṃ jalokṣitam /
column2: And placing his feet on the hoods of the serpent-king that were above the water he got hold of his bead with his hands.

column1: tasyāruroha sahasā madhyamaṃ tan mahac chiraḥ / so 'sya mūrdhni sthitaḥ kṛṣṇo nanarta rucirāṅgadaḥ //
column2: Then rising up, by force, on his middle head, Krishna, who was adorned with a beautiful Angada, began to dance there.

column1: mṛdyamānaḥ sa kṛṣṇena śrāntamūrdhā bhujaṃgamaḥ /
column2: Thus grinded by Krishna the hoods of that serpent-king became pale and blood came out therefrom.

column1: asyaiḥ sarudhirodgāraiḥ kātaraṃ vākyam abravīt //
column2: Kālya then with dreadful accents said to him.

column1: avijñānān mayā kṛṣṇa roṣo 'yaṃ saṃpradarśitaḥ /
column2: Krishna of a beautiful countenance, unwittingly did display anger against thee.

column1: damito 'haṃ hataviṣo vaśagas te varānana //
column2: But now have been vanquished and subdued by thee and my venom has been destroyed.

column1: śaraṇaṃ tvāṃ prapanno 'smi jīvitaṃ me pradīyatām //
column2: Do thou give me my life and command me whom am to serve along with my wife, children and friends –.

column1: ity uktvā sa śirobhis tu kṛṣṇapādāv apūjayat / pañcamūrdhānataṃ dṛṣṭvā sarpaṃ sarpāriketanaḥ / akruddha eva bhagavān pratyuvācorageśvaram //
column2: Beholding that five-hooded serpent-king and hearing his distressful words, the Lord Krishna, having the enemy of serpents as his carrier, replied like one having no anger :— serpent, do not wish to allow you to live in this water of Yamunā.

column1: gacchārṇavajalaṃ sarpa saputraḥ sahabāndhavaḥ //
column2: Therefore repair to the ocean with your wife and kinsmen.

column2: After this whoever amongst your sons and servants shall be seen either in the water or on the land of this province he will be killed by me.

column1: śivaṃ cāsya jalasyāstu tvaṃ ca gaccha mahārṇavam /
column2: king of serpents, let this water prove wholesome unto all and yourself proceed to the mighty deep.

column1: sthāne tv iha bhaved doṣas tavāntakaraṇo mahān //
column2: If you remain here after this you will be visited by a great calamity that will bring about the termination of your life.

column1: garudaḥ pannagaripus tvayi na prahariṣyati //
column2: If Garuda, the enemy of serpents, behold in the ocean, my foot-marks on your head he will not kill you.

column1: gṛhya mūrdhnā tu caraṇau kṛṣṇasyoragapuṃgavaḥ / paśyatām eva gopānāṃ jagāmādarśanaṃ hradāt //
column2: Thus accosted by the Lord that foremost of serpents Kalya, carrying on his head Krishna’s foot-marks, fled away stealthily from the lake in the very presence of the milk-men.

column1: nirjite tu gate sarpe kṛṣṇam uttīrya viṣṭhitam /
column2: After the king of serpents had thus fled away vanquished the Lord came out from the water and stood on the bank.

column1: vismitās tuṣṭuvur gopāś cakruś caiva pradakṣiṇam //
column2: Filled with surprise the milk-men chanted his glories and circumambulated him.

column2: Thereupon those milk-men, living in the forest, delightedly said to Nanda: Indeed thou art fortunate and a favourite of the gods since your son is so very powerful.

column1: adyaprabhṛti gopānāṃ gavāṃ ghoṣasya cānagha / āpatsu śaraṇaṃ kṛṣṇaḥ prabhuś cāyatalocanaḥ //
column2: From to-day, sinless one, the powerful Krishna, having large eyes, will be a refuge of the milk-men in their perils and a protector of the kine in the cow-shed.

column1: jātā śivajalā sarvā yamunā munisevitā /
column2: The water of the Yamunā has become everywhere delightful and wholesome.

column1: sarvais tīrthaiḥ sukhaṃ gāvo vicariṣyanti naḥ sadā //
column2: From now all our kine will happily range in every landing stair.

column1: vyaktam eva vayaṃ gopā vane yat kṛṣṇam īdṛśam /
column2: Really we are milk-men for we have not been able to know Krishna truly in Vraja like fire covered with ashes.

column2: Thereupon eulogising the immortal Krishna the milk-men, filled with surprise, entered their hamlet like unto the celestials entering the Chitraratha garden.

column2: Vaishampayana said:—After the king of serpents had been vanquished by Krishna in the lake of Yamunā Rāma and Keshava began to range there.

column2: Thereupon going to the mountain Govarddhana along with their precious kine, those two heroic sens of Vasudeva beheld a huge forest of palm trees, situate, on its north, on the bank of Yamunā -.

column1: tau tālaparṇapratate ramye tālavane ratau / ceratuḥ paramaprītau vṛṣapotāv ivodgatau //
column2: They were greatly delighted at its sight and began to range in that charming forest of palm trees covered with palm leaves like two new grown plants.

column2: It was well levelled, cool, coated with black earth and profuse grass and was freed from stones and clods of earth. Dark-blue and tall palm trees, with fruits and branches hanging, shone there like the trunks of elephants –.

column2: While thus ranging Dāmodara, the foremost of speakers, said to Sangkarshana:— reverend sir, this forest-land is perfumed with the fragrance of ripe palm fruits.

column1: tālapakvāni sahitau pātayāvo laghukramau //
column2: Let us both quickly pluck the sweet, ripe and dark-blue fruits.

column1: yady eṣām īdṛśo gandho madhuro ghrānasaṃmataḥ / rasenāmṛtakalpena bhaviṣyantīti me matiḥ //
column2: While its smell is so very sweet and pleasing to the odiferous organ it must undoubtedly be delicious like ambrosia. This is in short my conviction –.

column1: dāmodaravacaḥ śrutvā rauhiṇeyo hasann iva / pātayaṃs tālapakvāni cālayām āsa tāṃs tarūn //
column2: Hearing the words of Dāmodara, Rohini’s son smilingly shook the trees with a view of felling down the fruits.

column1: dāruṇo dhenuko nāma daityo gardabharūpavān / kharayūthena mahatā vṛtaḥ samupasevate //
column2: For encircled by a herd of mules that huge and dreadful demon Dhenuka used always to live there, in the shape of an ass.

column1: nṛpakṣiśvāpadagaṇāṃs trāsayānaḥ sa durmatiḥ //
column2: Terrifying men, beasts and birds there that wicked minded ass used to protect the forest of palm trees.

column1: tālaśabdaṃ sa taṃ śrutvā saṃghuṣṭaṃ phalapātane /
column2: Hearing the sound of the fall of palm fruits he grew exceedingly enraged and could not bear it like unto an elephant.

column1: stabdhākṣo heṣitapaṭuḥ khurair nirdārayan mahīm // āviddhapuccho hṛṣito vyāttānana ivāntakaḥ / āpatann eva dadṛśe rauhiṇeyam avasthitam //
column2: Shaking his manes in anger, lifting up his tail in delight and scratching the earth with his hoof that Daitya, of motionless eyes and wide lips, followed the sound of palm fruits and arrived where the son of Rohini was –.

column2: Beholding under the palm tree that immortal son of Rohini resembling a flag in form, that Daitya-chief Khara, having the teeth for his weapon, all on a sudden bit him; and then turning back his face he struck his breast with his long legs – Then holding that demon in the shape of an ass by the legs and whirling his head and shoulders Sangkarshana threw him up on the top of the palm tree.

column1: kharas tālaphalaiḥ sārdhaṃ papāta dharaṇītale //
column2: He too, with his thighs, waist, neck and back mutilated and a disfigured form, fell down on earth along with palm fruits.

column1: jñātīṃs tathāparāṃs tasya cikṣepa tṛṇarājani //

column1: sā bhūr gardabhadehaiś ca tālapakvaiś ca pātitaiḥ / babhāse channajaladā dyaur ivāvyaktaśāradī //
column2: At that time the ground there was covered with palm fruits and bodies of the asses and it shone there like the autumnal sky covered with clouds.

column1: tasmin gardabhadaiteya tu sānuge vinipātite / ramyaṃ tālavanaṃ tadd hi bhūyo ramyataraṃ babhau // vipramuktabhayaṃ śubhraṃ viviktākāradarśanam /

column1: tataḥ pravyāhṛtāḥ sarve gopā vananivāsinaḥ /
column2: And entering that forest the milkmen, rangers of woods, began to move about on all sides divested of sorrow and fear.

column2: Observing the kine roam on all sides at ease the two sons of Vasudeva, powerful like elephants, spread there seats of grass and sat down at ease.

column1: vaiśaṃpāyana uvāca atha tau jātaharṣau tu vasudevasutāv ubhau /
column2: Vaishampayana said:—Thereupon leaving off that forest of palm trees the two sons of Vasudeva again came to the Bhandira tree.

column1: cārayantau vivṛddhāni godhanāni śubhānanau / sphītasasyaprarūḍhāni vīkṣamāṇau vanāni ca //
column2: Traversing that prosperous forest land and tending the ever increasing flock of kine those two beautiful subduers of enemies began to strike their arms and sing.

column1: nāmabhir vyāharantau ca savatsā gāḥ paraṃtapau //
column2: Sometimes they collected the trees and called the kine with their calves by names –.

column2: They had ropes hanging on their shoulders and their breasts were adorned with garlands of auspicious wild flowers. And they looked like two bulls with new-grown horns.

column2: Having the hue of gold and powdered collyrium and clad in apparels of the same color with their respective persons, those two boys appeared like white and black clouds accompanied by rain-bow.

column2: Traversing the forest-ways along with their comrades, making beautiful ear-rings with the tips of Kuçā grass or flowers, and putting on wild dresses they sometimes sported on the mount Govardhana, sometimes in the forest and some times in the table-land.

column1: ceratur lokasiddhābhiḥ krīḍābhir aparājitau //
column2: They thus engaged in a sport which was celebrated all over the world -.

column1: tāv enaṃ mānuṣīṃ dīkṣāṃ vahantau surapūjitau / tajjātiguṇayuktābhiḥ krīḍābhiś ceratur vanam //
column2: Thus following human conduct and engaging in a play introduced by milk-men they, who were worshipful even unto the celestials, began to range in the forest.

column1: tatra spandolikābhiś ca yuddhamārgaiś ca daṃśitau /
column2: They, who were experts in fighting, began to play there with cradles, nets and stones.

column1: tayo ramayator evaṃ tallipsur asurottamaḥ / pralambo 'bhyāgamat teṣāṃ chidrānveṣī tayos tadā //
column2: While they were thus playing, the foremost of Asuras, by name Pralamva, came there with a view to kill them and began to find out their weak points.

column2: Assuming the form of a cow-herd and adorned with wild flowers that Asura began to tempt the two brothers with his play and smiles.

column1: mānuṣaṃ vapur āsthāya pralambo dānavottamaḥ //
column2: Adopting a human form, although not born in the race of men that foremost of Dānavas, fearlessly joined their company.

column1: prakrīḍitāś ca te sarve saha tenāmarāriṇā / gopālavapuṣaṃ gopā manyamānāḥ svabāndhavam //
column2: Considering him, who came there in the form of a milk-man, as their friend, those cow-herds began to play with that enemy of the immortals.

column1: dṛṣṭiṃ paridadhe kṛṣṇe rauhiṇeye ca dāruṇām //
column2: Searching their weak points Pralamva too, who had assumed the guise of a milk-man, cast his dreadful looks at Krishna and Rohini's son.

column1: prakrīḍitāś ca te sarve dvau dvau yugapad utpatan //

column1: pradrutā laṅghayanto vai te 'nyonyaṃ laghuvikramāḥ //

column2: Then that huge-faced and huge-necked dreadful demon, having eyes like unto the wheels of a car, a head adorned with a sun-like coronet of five layers and resembling Death himself, shone like a cloud attacked by the sun.

column2: The earth sank under the weight of his feet -.

column1: hriyamāṇaḥ pralambena sa tu saṃkarṣaṇo yuvā / uhyamāna ivaikena kālameghena candramāḥ //
column2: While thus carried away by him Sangkarshana shone there like the moon in the sky carried by dreadful clouds –.

column1: vijayati vasudhāṃ ca kṣatravṛttir dhanam atulaṃ labhate dviṣajjayaṃ ca /
column2: Bhārata is the most excellent refuge –. The Bhārata is superior to all Shāstras, Through Bhārata one can acquire Moksha emancipation.

column1: vipulam api dhanaṃ labhec ca vaiśyaḥ sugatim iyāc chravaṇāc ca śūdrajātiḥ // purāṇam etac caritaṃ mahātmanām adhītya buddhiṃ labhate ca naiṣṭhikīm /
column2: foremost of Bhāratas, in the beginning, middle and end of the Vedas, Rāmāyana and Mahābhārata Hari has been described. Man, wishing to acquire the great station, should listen to the recitation of the glorious deeds of Vishnu and Srutis. This great work is the cannon of religion and is endued with all virtues.

column1: vihāya duḥkhāni vimuktasaṅgaḥ sa vītarāgo vicared vasuṃdharām //
column2: Vishnu, thou art without birth and decay, thou art the only One worthy of being meditated upon. Thou art gross and subtle and art beyond the reach of perception. Thou art Saguna and Nirguna.

column1: ity etad ākhyānam udāhṛtaṃ vaḥ pratismaranto dvijamaṇḍaleṣu / sthairyeṇa jātena punaḥ smarantaḥ sukhaṃ bhavanto vicarantu lokam //
column2: Thou art the preceptor of the three worlds and creator. seek refuge with thee. May all tide over calamities, may all meet with well-being, and may all acquire their wished-for objects for the completion of the recitation of the Bhārata -.

column1: iti caritam idaṃ mahātmanām ṛṣikṛtam adbhutavīryakarmaṇām /
column2: Forsooth does a Vaishnava reap, by listening to Harivamsha, the fruits yielded by the hearing of the eighteen Puranas.

column1: kathitam idaṃ hi samāsavistaraiḥ kim aparam icchasi kiṃ bravīmi te //
column2: king, you should give lands unto the Bramhanas. There is no other gift like it and there will be none -.
